justification: The text states that "A classic method that produces such effects, the 'free choice paradigm' (Brehm 1956) is still widely used," referring to research on cognitive dissonance.
It notes that the aversive state of dissonance "is also revealed by covert measures such as affect misattribution (Zanna & Cooper, 1974; Losch & Cacciopo 1990)."
The article lists "psychophysiology (Losch & Cacciopo 1990; Harmon-Jones et al 1996)" as a method detecting the discomfort of dissonance.
Functional neuroimaging is mentioned among the covert measures: "functional neuroimaging (van Veen et al, 2009)" that reveal the dissonance state.
